note.p: Jehu Amaziah Orr was a representative of Mississippi in the Confederate States Congress during the Civil War.

Born on May 10, 1828, in Anderson County, South Carolina, he moved to Mississippi as a child. He graduated from Erskine College in South Carolina, before attending Princeton University in late 1840s. He left Princeton before graduation due to illness, but returned to earn a Master’s degree there in 1857. Orr became a prominent figure in Mississippi politics as a young man, being appointed as secretary to a Mississippi state convention on slavery in 1849, and later serving as secretary of the Mississippi Senate, a state representation, a district attorney, and then in 1861 being elected a delegate to Mississippi’s secession convention.

Once Mississippi joined the Confederacy, Orr won a seat representing Mississippi at the Confederate Provisional Congress in Montgomery, Alabama. In early 1862, he stepped away from politics to command the Thirty-First Mississippi Infantry Regiment. He led the unit through several battles, until 1864 when he returned to politics and took a seat in the Confederate House of Representatives, which he held until the end of the Civil War.

After the war Orr returned to practicing law. He served as judge of Mississippi’s Sixth Judicial District from 1869 to 1876, and then ran a very successful law firm, serving as the attorney for the Mobile & Ohio Railroad Company. He was married to Cornelia Ewing Van de Graaff and had four children. Late in his life, Orr became an outspoken supporter of women’s voting rights alongside his daughter Pauline Van de Graaff Orr, a notable suffragist. He was among the last surviving members of the Confederate Congress, and was widely praised in the early twentieth century for his more progressive views toward racial and social equality compared to his former Confederate colleagues.
Orr died in on March 9, 1921, at his daughter’s home in New York. He was 92 years old. He is buried in Friendship Cemetery in Columbus, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; Jessica R. Mack, “Jehu A. Orr,” Princeton & Slavery; St. Louis Post-Dispatch, St. Louis, MO, April 24, 1910; The Columbus Dispatch, Columbus, MS, March 13, 1921)

William Feimster Tucker was a Confederate general during the Civil War.

Born on May 9, 1827, in Iredell County, North Carolina, Tucker graduated from Emory and Henry College in Virginia in 1848. He moved to Houston, Mississippi, and studied law, soon securing a seat as probate judge in Chickasaw County.

Tucker volunteered for Confederate military service when the Civil War broke out in 1861. He was commissioned as a captain in the Eleventh Mississippi Infantry Regiment and saw action at the First Battle of Bull Run. Tucker was later transferred to the western theater, and placed in command of the Forty-first Mississippi Infantry Regiment, where he participated in several battles in Kentucky and Tennessee in 1862 and 1863. In March 1864, he was promoted to brigadier general and commanded Confederate troops against Union forces under William Tecumseh Sherman during the Atlanta Campaign. Tucker was severely wounded at the Battle of Resaca in May 1864 and was forced to retire from field duty. He recovered enough to hold take command of the District of Southern Mississippi and East Louisiana during the final weeks of the war.

After the Civil War, Tucker returned to Mississippi to practice law. He ran for state political office at the end of Reconstruction, winning two terms in the state’s House of Representatives in the late 1870s. He was murdered on September 14, 1881, in Okolona, Mississippi, when an unknown assailant fired a gun through Tucker’s bedroom window, killing him instantly. The death was suspected to be an assassination, possibly stemming from one of Tucker’s legal cases. Several people were questioned, and two men arrested, but no one was convicted of the murder.
Tucker was married to Martha Josephine Chackelford. The couple had at least six children that lived to adulthood. Tucker is buried at Odd Fellows Cemetery in Okolona, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; N.C. Hughes, Jr., “Tucker, William Feimster,” NCPedia; Christopher Losson, “William Feimster Tucker,” Mississippi Encyclopedia)

note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

James M. Thomson (sometimes spelled Thompson) was a lawyer, Mississippi state Senator, and Quartermaster of the First Mississippi Infantry (militia).

Born on June 8, 1830 in Alabama, Thomson was a lawyer and enslaver living in Chickasaw County, Mississippi by 1850. In 1860, he became a state Senator for Chickasaw County, and he was an outspoken proponent of secession. During the Civil War, he resigned his seat in the Senate and joined the First Mississippi Infantry (militia). He served as the Quartermaster for the regiment in 1861 and was captured in October 1862 in Corinth, Mississippi. He was released by July 1863 and returned to his work as a Quartermaster. His actions after the war are unclear, suggesting he may have died during the war. Thomson was married to Martha Thomson. The pair had at least two children.

(U.S. Census Record for Chickasaw County, Mississippi, 1850; U.S. Census Record for Chickasaw County, Mississippi, 1860; The Prairie News, September 8, 1859; T. N. Martin to Mississippi Governor John J. Pettus, September 12, 1861, Civil War & Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, mdah_757-939-07-43; J. M. Thomson to Colonel Joseph Bennett, May 18, 1861, Civil War & Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, mdah_764-948-14-07; U.S., Confederate Army Casualty Lists and Reports, 1861-1865; The Weekly Mississippian, June 6, 1860; James Thomson to Mississippi Governor John J. Pettus, July 1, 1863, Civil War & Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, mdah_757-945-04-04)

note.p: Charles Clark served as Mississippi’s governor during the last two years of the Civil War. Born in Cincinnati, Ohio, on May 24, 1811, Clark later moved to Mississippi, where he became a lawyer and a state representative in the late 1830s. After successfully representing a Mississippi settler in a land dispute with members of the Choctaw Nation in the early 1840s, Clark received a large tract of land near Beulah, Mississippi, as payment. Clark eventually enlarged his property to over five thousand acres, making it one of the largest and most successful plantations in Mississippi. During this time, he married Ann Eliza Darden and between 1840 and 1852 fathered three children.

Clark volunteered for military service during the Mexican-American War in 1846 and raised a company of volunteers that was placed into the 2nd Mississippi Regiment. After its original commander resigned, Clark was elected colonel. Following the war in 1848, he returned to Mississippi resumed an interest in politics. He was selected as a delegate to a state convention in 1851 that debated the matter of secession in the wake of the Compromise of 1850, which had tried to settle a fierce dispute over the fate of slavery in territories gained by the United States from Mexico. Clark attended the convention as a Unionist, opposed to withdrawing from the Union. Developments over the next ten years changed his mind.

Clark won a seat in the Mississippi’s House of Representatives as a Whig, serving from 1856 to 1861. Following Abraham Lincoln’s election as president in 1860, Clark embraced Mississippi’s secession. When the Civil War broke out, Clark received a commission as a brigadier general in the Mississippi Militia. He later entered the Confederate Army and eventually took command of a division. Slightly wounded at the Battle of Shiloh in April 1862, he was more seriously wounded and captured during fighting at Baton Rouge, Louisiana, in August 1862. Clark spent a short time as a prisoner of war before he was paroled by Union forces.

In 1863, Clark ran for governor of Mississippi, in the wake of Confederate defeats at Vicksburg and Jackson. Clark campaigned on continued resistance to the Union and easily won the executive seat. Due to Union campaigns in Mississippi, Clark periodically moved the state government, from Jackson to Macon, then to Columbus, and back to Macon. When Confederate forces in Mississippi surrendered in May 1865, Clark instructed the state legislature to convene for a special session in Jackson. In June 1865, federal troops at Jackson arrested Clark and imprisoned him at Fort Pulaski, Georgia.

Eventually released from federal custody, Clark returned to Bolivar County, Mississippi. He quietly practiced law and served on the University of Mississippi Board of Trustees during Reconstruction. In 1876, Clark received an appointment as chancellor for the fourth judicial district. He died a year later, on December 17, 1877. Clark is buried in a family cemetery at Beulah, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; David Sansing, “Charles Clark: Twenty-fourth Governor of Mississippi: 1863–1865,” Mississippi History Now; FindaGrave)

place.placeName: Navy-yards and naval stations--Pensacola Navy Yard (Fla.)

note.p: Located at Pensacola, Florida, the Pensacola Navy Yard (also known as the Warrington Navy Yard) was established in 1825 as the first U.S. navy yard on the Gulf of Mexico. The site was chosen in part by U.S. Navy officer Lewis Warrington, who oversaw construction of the shipyard facilities and created a nearby village that also bore his name. Confederates took possession of the navy yard on January 12, 1861, shortly after Florida's secession. In May 1862, Confederate leaders abandoned it in order to send reinforcements to field armies in the west, and the garrison set fire to the facilities before departing. Union troops occupying a nearby island rushed into the navy yard and extinguished the flames before all of the facilities burned. Federal forces occupied it for the rest of the war, using it to service ships blockading the Confederacy in the Gulf. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: When the 13th Amendment abolished slavery, it failed to abolish involuntary servitude. The amendment included a loophole banning involuntary servitude "except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have been duly convicted" (Library of Congress). White southerners in the post-emancipation South, concerned about both the availability of labor and the freedom of African Americans, manipulated this clause and turned to convict leasing to entrench long standing racial hierarchies.

Immediately after the war, many states passed "Black Codes" or laws severely limiting African Americans' rights. Under these codes and other similar laws passed in the decades following the Civil War, African Americans could be arrested for any number of petty crimes, including vagrancy (functionally construed to mean any act of social mobility not approved by a white person) or theft (in Mississippi a felony if exceeding $10 worth of goods). Widespread racism and stereotypes about Black criminality led to a dramatic expansion in the population of imprisoned individuals and an overwhelming number of African Americans within that population. Many states leased those convicted persons to private companies or individuals for their labor, and in certain cases lessees had been the pre-emancipation enslaver of the leased.

Laborers worked in a variety of settings including shipbuilding and timber cutting, yet the most prominent form in states like Mississippi remained large-scale agricultural work. The convict lease system was incredibly dangerous and difficult for those who lived through it, as leased persons faced unsafe working conditions, inadequate living conditions, abuse from lessees, and grueling work schedules. Given these circumstances, the ready availability of imprisoned laborers, and the callousness of lessees and state officials, the mortality rate among convict laborers was incredibly high.

Certain states ceased leasing imprisoned persons to individuals or private companies in the late nineteenth century, only to continue using that labor on state-funded infrastructure projects like road or highway construction until, in some cases, World War II. Southern individuals and states thereby continued to increase their wealth through the coerced labor of African Americans while perpetuating anti-Black racism and laying the foundations of the modern prison-industrial complex (Library of Congress; Mississippi Encyclopedia).

In the wake of the Civil War, many states turned to convict leasing to bolster infrastructural repair and to maintain long standing racial hierarchies. Like many other southern states, Mississippi instituted a convict leasing program, and in 1876 the state passed the Leasing Act (commonly known as the “Pig Law”), which sentenced anyone who stole property valued at $10 or greater up to five years in prison and quadrupled the prison population, with Black prisoners comprising approximately 85% of inmates. The state most frequently leased convicted persons to individuals, primarily to perform agricultural work on cotton farms.

However, the state also leased incarcerated persons to private companies, such as the Gulf & Ship Island Railroad Company, and companies subjected convict-laborers to excruciating working conditions with little shelter, sustenance, or medical care. While companies and private individuals leased enslaved workers during the antebellum era, enslavers expected “their human chattel to be returned alive and in good working condition” (Sturkey, Hattiesburg). However, this expectation was virtually nonexistent in postwar convict leasing programs. The death toll therefore grew to staggering heights. In response, Mississippi cancelled Gulf & Ship Island’s contract in December 1888 and ceased leasing convicts to private companies in 1890. However, the state and individual counties and towns continued to use convict labor for public works projects and at the state’s penitentiary at Parchman plantation well into the twentieth century (Mississippi Encyclopedia).

During the American Civil War, to disband a military unit was to formally dissolve it. Once dissolved, soldiers returned to their state capitals to deposit their weapons and other publicly owned property. Units were disbanded for a number of reasons throughout the war, including the end of their service agreement and surrender. Frequently, officers disbanded a unit with diminished strength and reorganized it to form a full strength unit. As the Lieber Code did not recognize un-uniformed guerrilla fighters, it was also common for leaders of guerrilla units, like Confederate Col. John Singleton Mosby, to disband their command rather than formally surrender.

Following Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee's surrender of the Army of Northern Virginia at Appomattox Court House in April 1864, the enormous process of demobilizing all Confederate armies began. The terms for disbanding Confederate military units Union Gen. Ulysses S. Grant offered Lee were mimicked by other Union commanders. Rather that disbanding the men without any restraints, Grant classified them as paroled prisoners of war, which would legally forbid them for taking up arms against the United States again. (Caroline E. Janney, Ends of War, p. 26; 47)

gloss.p: The Confederate Army was the military land force of the Confederate States of America during the American Civil War. Known also as the Confederate States Army or Southern Army, it was established by the Provisional Confederate Congress in February 1861 and fell under the authority of Confederate President Jefferson Davis. Modeled after the U.S. Army of the 19th century, the Confederate Army technically fell into two categories: a small regular army of professional officers and soldiers (the Army of the Confederate States of America) and a much larger, temporary force of citizen soldiers intended to exist only for the duration of the war (the Provisional Army of the Confederate States). In reality, the Confederacy’s regular army never fully developed and the overwhelming majority of Confederate soldiers served in the provisional force. The distinction between the two played little role during military operations and all were generally considered to be part of the overall Confederate Army.

As many as 1,000,000 soldiers served in the Confederate Army between 1861 and 1865, although not all at one time. Most were volunteers, however, the Confederate government instituted a conscription (or draft) in April 1862—the first in U.S. or Confederate history—to increase the size of the Confederacy’s military force and encourage voluntary enlistment. The government passed two more conscription acts over the next two years. More than ten percent of the men who served in Confederate ranks were drafted.

Over ninety percent of soldiers in the Confederate Army were native-born white men. Nine percent were foreign-born white men. Several Native American units—particularly from the Cherokee, Creek, and Choctaw tribes—served within the Confederate military, especially in the trans-Mississippi theatre. The Confederate military heavily relied upon the forced labor of enslaved African Americans for building fortifications and carrying out menial tasks, and the Confederate government did not formally allow African Americans (free or slave) to join the army until a last minute desperate measure passed the Confederate Congress in March 1865, only weeks before the end of the war. Only around two hundred enslaved soldiers were organized into service, but they were not sent into combat.

By the time the last Confederate soldiers surrendered to Union forces in June 1865, nearly 100,000 had been killed in combat or succumbed to wounds, more than 160,000 had died of disease, and roughly 30,000 had died in prison camps. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: The 11th Regiment, Mississippi Infantry (Confederate) was organized on May 4, 1861 in Alcorn County, Mississippi under the command of Col. William H. Moore and served in the Eastern Theater under Whiting's, Law's, and Davis' Brigade in the Army of Northern Virginia. It was later commanded by Cols. Phillip Frank Lidell, Francis M. Greene, William H. Moore, and Reuben O. Reynolds. (Howell, Jr., Military History of Mississippi, 19; Rowland, Official and Statistical Register of Mississippi, 436-444; National Park Service-Battle Units)

gloss.p: Operating nationally, the Provisional Confederate Congress established the War Department by an act on February 21, 1861, in Montgomery, Alabama. The department was led by the Secretary of War, appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate. It was initially led by LeRoy Pope Walker from February 25–September 16, 1861 and later led by Judah P. Benjamin (September 17, 1861–March 24, 1862), George W. Randolph (March 24–November 15, 1862), James Seddon (November 21, 1862–February 5, 1865), and Maj. Gen. John C. Breckinridge (February 6–May 10, 1865). The War Department was responsible for the administration of the Confederate Army and managed all matters pertaining to American Indian tribes within the boundaries of the Confederate States. (Acts and Resolutions of the First Session of the Provisional Congress of the Confederate States, 1861 Public Laws, S1, 46; Wikipedia)

gloss.p: The Provisional Confederate Congress established the Confederate Quartermaster Department on February 26, 1861 in Montgomery, Alabama under the War Department. Initially under the command of Col. Abraham C. Myers, Brig Gen. Alexander Lawton assumed command in 1863. Operating at the national level of the Confederacy, the Quartermaster Department was responsible for procuring war materials and other supplies for the Confederate Army. (Laws of the Provisional Congress of the Confederate States, 1861, 4; American Battlefield Trust; Wikipedia)

gloss.p: "Mississippi State Penitentiary, also known as Parchman Farm, is a maximum-security prison farm located in unincorporated Sunflower County, Mississippi, in the Mississippi Delta region. Occupying about 28 square miles (73 km2) of land, Parchman is the only maximum security prison for men in the state of Mississippi, and is the state's oldest prison." (Wikipedia)

The Cambridge Dictionary defines and imprisoned person as "a person who is kept in prison as a punishment" (Cambridge Dictionary). CWRGM, however, adopts the subject tag "Imprisoned people" to emphasize the personhood of those who have been imprisoned for crimes. This tag recognizes the systemic injustice and dehumanization historically present in the American carceral system wherein many have been falsely convicted and therefore uses the term "imprisoned" to reflect a person's having been placed in prison, while giving primacy to their personhood and not rendering judgement on that person's guilt (Akiba Solomon, "Words We Use," The Marshall Project).

div.p:
Hon. J. J. Pettus.
Governor &c
Jackson
Miss.

I dislike very much to trouble you with business that does not belong to your office, but if the proper officers have been appointed I have not learned the fact, and I hope you will excuse me for addressing you in person. My Company (the Chickasaw Guards) are not supplied with tents or knapsacks & Mr J. M. Thomson informs me that you are having tents made by the convicts in the Peniten-tiary for the use of the Volunteer companies of the State; Mr. Buchanan goes down to represent our Company & to remain until we can be furnished with both tents and knapsacks if it be possible to supply them. We have just returned from Pensacola Navy Yard & while in service felt as you may suppose the need of these indispensable articles.
Gen. Clark has furnished you with our muster roll before this no doubt containing the time each man had served with the omission of the day we
disbanded, a fact which we could not know at the time the report was furnished. We arrived at home on the 7th day of Feb. & you will please permit Mr. Buchanan to have this entry made in our report.

A grave question presents itself under the late military bill with regard to those companies that under your orders had assembled at Pensacola. Will they be considered as mustered into the service of the State and take rank accordingly or will they be compelled after their return home formally to tender their services to the Executive & take rank below those companies which remained at home & they had an opportunity of reporting themselves immediately after the passage of the Bill? I hope no such decision as this will be made. We considered ourselves in the service of the State at the time the bill passed & all we ask is that our Company may be consider-ed by your Excellency to have tendered their ser-vices and that you accepted the same in accordance with terms of the Bill.

This is a subject of much interest not only to my own but to all the Miss. Companies that were in Florida & I shall be pleased to know your decision on this point at an early a day as possible. From what I have heard from Miss Baldwin & Orr I think it very possible your Excellency was

laboring under a misapprehension as to the disat-isfaction among the volunteers in Florida when we were ordered home. It is true we thought we were ordered there to take Fort Pickens as soon as we arrived & the troops would have been better satisfied to have had a fight every day but so far as gallantry & soldierly conduct are concerned volunteers never behave better with nothing but camp duties to perform & I am sure the honor of Miss. was safe in their hands either in camp or field. In the difficulty about field officers of which I hear you were informed my Company took no part as we were not from Albert's regiment nor in the same Brigade as the other companies & we left them to settle their own disputes.

If a Quarter Master has been appointed I hope you will give us your influence with him to dispatch Mr. Buchanan home with a complete outfit of tents camp stools knapsacks &c and if no one has been appointed make a spe-cial appoint,ent for our benefit. The political horizon looks equally & if Miss. needs our ser-vices as she may any hour we wish to be fully equipped & ready at a minutes war-ning. You will please accept our thanks for placing the Chickasaw Guards first in your late order

W. F. Tucker
Capt. Chickasaw Guards
Capt W. F. Lucker of The Chickasaw Guards
